body: This is a MUCH simplified example, the minimum necessary to reproduce the problem for the issue report.  As far as I can tell, this code _should_ work, and indeed did work prior to 4.2

The problem is that IncludeBase will create the base mappings for you. That is, all the base mappings in 4.2. And in this case the mapping it creates is not valid and it complains. #1069 was also possible because it created the base mapping you said, not the base mapping you wanted.
#911 made sense so it was fixed. I'm not sure why IncludeBase _creates_ the base mappings. @jbogard should know. But if we assume both these things, it's the right behavior.

#1069 was a previous attempt to make a reproducible version of this bug - my code was wrong, I accepted that.

I'm going to update my code to use the same terminology as #911 before continuing the discussion.
That's not the point :) The point is that AutoMapper might have reported the missing map, but it didn't. It created a new one and that's why the error was even possible.
Foo is a member of Dest through level 0. The level 0 map is missing. If you create it, the issue disappears, otherwise AutoMapper creates a default one that is invalid.

Pre-4.2, the Level 0 map was not required.  Your reasoning would make sense to me if the Level1 mapping was the problem, but removing the Level2 mapping from the profile causes the test to pass.

Pre 4.2, using .IncludeBase would just include the valid mapping defined for Level1 (which already includes Level0).

Now it seems to need a mapping which appears to be redundant - I'll never try and map to DestLevel0 as it's abstract, and I have to explicitly Ignore the property and then re-map it later on.
You don't have to re-map. Add the missing map and it works.

I think we're going round in circles.  The Level0 map is not needed by the Level1 map (remove the Level2 map and the profile is valid).  The Level0 map IS needed by the Level2 map which is trying to include Level1.

Behaviour of `IncludeBase` has changed from "Include how to map SrcLevel1 to DestLevel1" to "Include how to map SrcLevel1 to DestLevel1 **except inherited properties**".  If this is intentional then I think this was a confusing decision to make.  If it was not intentional, then this is a bug.
No it's not intentional, but I think I've restored the behavior in 5.0.
@Boychenko It works with the MyGet build.
@lbargaoanu As I understand MyGet version is 5.0. Am I right?
MyGet is always the latest version.

We're seeing this as well, and I would expect almost any medium-large project to run into this. Is 5.0 imminent? If not, is the change @jbogard mentioned small enough to be backported for a patch release? I would be happy do a PR if somebody pointed out the 5.0 fix commit
We have the same issue in our project. I agree with @mattzink, it would be nice to have this fix in a minor update.
